metadata.sermon_title: A Sound Word For A New Year
metadata.sermon_start_end: Following watch meeting services last Tuesday evening, I talked with two other pastors. Both of them had noticed in their congregations what I thought I detected here on watch meeting night. That is, an unusually grave and serious and even apprehensive mood. [...] Come, Lord Jesus, we are pilgrims in the night, children crying for the light.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: While the preacher identifies a specific and difficult text (Daniel 12), he quickly moves away from the particularity of the passage to general themes of 'waiting' and 'trying'. The sermon fails to identify what is in this text that can be found nowhere else; instead, it uses the text as a springboard for a general discourse on resilience.
quotes: I need not dwell upon the literal time span mentioned here... These days are not important; what is important is that something hurtful and painful which was going on would not go on forever.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: The preacher must take the 'literal time span' and the specific apocalyptic imagery seriously. By dismissing the details as 'not important', the sermon loses the specificity Dekker demands.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates adequate knowledge of the historical context (Antiochus, the Hasidim, the abomination of desolation). He relies on secondary scholarly authority (James Sanders) rather than direct engagement with the original languages, but the historical sketch is traceable.
quotes: The wicked and pagan king Antiochus turned his soldiers loose to pillage and plunder the city of God, Jerusalem.
As Dr. Sanders says in Torah and Canon, the writer of Daniel 'warns...'
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Integrate the exegesis more deeply into the theology of the sermon rather than treating it as a historical 'lesson' that is then left behind for psychological application.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application to the 1975 zeitgeist is strong and concrete. The preacher mentions specific political figures (Nixon, Ford, Johnson), social issues (Boston busing), and economic fears (unemployment). This aligns with Dekker's requirement for knowledge of the zeitgeist.
quotes: The cloud of unemployment seems to hang lower and lower over us...
Boston, is showing a resistance to a unitary, integrated public educational system...
the present president of the United States is an appointee of a pardoned president whose deeds of criminality are preserved forever electronically.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: The transition from these sharp cultural observations to the spiritual remedy becomes too general ('Lord, I've tried'). The application needs to remain as concrete as the diagnosis.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a traditional 'sandwich' structure: contemporary mood, then historical exegesis, then spiritual application. While there are attempts to link the 'abomination of desolation' to modern despair, the movement is more sequential than interwoven.
quotes: When we turn to the Book of Daniel, we discover that ours is surely not the first unhappy time...
I suppose that is what my sermon is all about this New Year's morning. Daniel talks to those who are in the grip of a terrible 2,290 days of trouble...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid separating the 'then' of Daniel from the 'now' of 1975. The hearer should be 'expounded' simultaneously with the text.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is heavily emphasized, which Dekker allows for certain texts. However, the 'redemption' offered leans heavily on human effort ('trying') rather than the objective work of Christ. Gratitude is largely absent, replaced by a weary persistence.
quotes: Lord, I've tried, Lord, I've really tried.
It is our job to try on and pray on.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Shift the focus from the subject's 'trying' to the objective redemption in Christ. The misery is well-articulated, but the solution is too anthropocentric.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on 'being lost in time' (social decay, loss of purpose), but it lacks the sharp edge of the 'two ways'. There is no real call to decision or warning of destruction; the tone is one of universal weariness rather than the urgency of a narrow way.
quotes: One does not brave the future by deciding to be a nobody... One braves the future by deciding... to live in the image of God.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher should articulate the 'ultimate possibilities' of the life design more sharply. What is the 'broad way' in 1975 that leads to destruction?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned only at the very end as a companion and a future hope. He is not the 'telos' that informs the entire sermon. The doctrine of the two natures is not utilized; Christ appears more as a sympathetic figure than the Lord who is the goal of the text.
quotes: And we have Christ to go with us to the end. He says, 'I will be with you.'
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Christ must be more than an appendix. The sermon needs to show how the specific text of Daniel points to Christ as the only salvation outside of man.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18 minutes, the sermon falls just short of Dekkerâ€™s 20-minute minimum. While it has social breadth, it lacks the exegetical depth required to sustain a truly 'proclamatory word' over the necessary duration.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the depth of the exegetical exposition to reach the 20-minute mark, ensuring that the 'breadth' is not just social commentary but scriptural depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong piece of social commentary that identifies the cultural 'misery' of 1975 with precision. However, it falls short of Dekker's ideal by treating the specific Bible passage as a general illustration for human resilience. The 'redemption' offered is too focused on human effort ('trying') and lacks a robust Christocentric telos. The specificity of the Daniel text is largely discarded in favor of general spiritual encouragement.
strengths: Concrete cultural analysis of the 1975 zeitgeist.
Clear identification of human 'misery' in both collective and personal forms.
Effective use of historical context to ground the 'abomination of desolation'.
weaknesses: Anthropocentric focus on 'trying' rather than the objective grace of Christ.
Dismissal of the specific details of the biblical text as 'not important'.
Lack of the 'two ways' urgency; the sermon is more comforting than challenging.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate social-religious speech, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the necessary recreation of the specific Bible passage into a new, current, proclamatory word where Christ is the clear telos.
